Award.AwardTitle: Sensing Mechanism and Persistence of Semiconductor Gas Sensors on Nanostructured Surfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
1031111
Mengyan Shen
University of Massachusetts, Lowell

The objective of this project is to obtain a fundamental understanding of the sensing mechanism, persistence, and reliability of semiconductor oxide gas sensors on substrates formed through femtosecond laser nanostructuring combined with soft nanolithography. At room temperature, these recently discovered structures exhibit a higher sensitivity than conventional semiconductor gas sensors operating at 450Â°C. This eliminates problems such as high energy consumption, rapid degradation, and poor reliability. Since the low-temperature sensing mechanism cannot be ascribed solely to the high surface-to-bulk ratio of the substrates, the molecular-level function of these sensors will be studied through a physics-based predictive model.
Successful outcomes from this research are expected to (a) contribute to the areas of gas sensing and nanoscience and technology; and (b) enhance our knowledge of applications of bionics in enhancing the functions of detectors. The proposed research will lead to energy-saving and cost-effective sensors with a positive impact on the environment, which benefits consumers and society as a whole.
Educational and outreach programs based on this research will broaden the participation of women and other underrepresented groups in science and technology, and train future multidisciplinary scientists and engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to obtain a fundamental understanding of the sensing mechanism, persistence, and reliability of semiconductor oxide gas sensors at low temperature on substrates formed through femtosecond laser nanostructuring combined with soft nanolithography. At temperatures less than 100°C, these discovered structures exhibit a higher sensitivity than conventional semiconductor gas sensors operating at 450°C. This eliminates problems such as high energy consumption, rapid degradation, and poor reliability. Since the low-temperature sensing mechanism cannot be ascribed solely to the high surface-to-bulk ratio of the substrates, the molecular-level function of these sensors has been studied through a physics-based predictive model. The research will enable the creation of low cost, highly sensitive and reliable gas sensors to increase the safety of environments where hazardous gases such as ammonia (NH3) and carbon monoxide (CO) may appear.

The research has proved that very strong local electrical fields are formed around the sharp points of semiconductor nanostructures because electrons accumulate in these regions to maintain a constant electric potential (Figure 1). Dipolar molecules like CO are attracted to these regions, which makes the sensing possible at temperature lower than 100° C. This sensing mechanism also helps us to distinguish various gases, which will significantly improve the performance and capability of such low-temperature gas sensors.

Low temperature sensing allows us use polymer substrates to make sensors at low cost. We have successfully prepared SnO2 thin-film gas sensors on nanospike-structured polyurethane (PU) polymer surfaces, which were replicated by a low-cost soft nanolithography method from silicon nanospike structures. Because these low-cost sensors operate at low temperature, they can also be self-cleaning when subjected to water droplets (Figure 2), and we found that the self-cleaning can be repeated for more a thousand times.

Insights obtained from this research will (a) contribute to the areas of gas sensing and nanoscience and technology; and (b) enhance our knowledge of applications of biomimetics in enhancing the functions of detectors (e.g., we have increased the persistence of the sensors by using the "lotus effect" to create superhydrophobic surfaces). The proposed research will lead to energy-saving and cost-effective sensors with a positive impact on the environment, which benefits consumers and society as a whole. A total of six graduate students (including one female student) participated in and contributed to this project, five of them obtained their Ph. D. and one obtained a Master degree. Four undergraduate students (including one female student) were involved in the research and were trained on various aspects of this project.  The PI introduced the knowledge obtained in this project to his classes at UMass Lowell and in seminars at other institutions.  The research results were reported at five sensor related conferences and published in three journal papers. Educational and outreach programs based on this research have broadened the participation of women and other underrepresented groups in science and technology, and trained future multidisciplinary scientists and engineers.
